timeline.message:
Shared reference abstraction.

We introduce the notion of shared reference that generalizes `Ref<>` and
`Intern<>`.

Summary
-------

`Ref` and `Intern` types have the same purpose (but different
performance characteristics) and similar semantics.  The compiler has
some amount of builtin support for both of them.  This patch generalizes
this support by abstracting away both types as shared references.  It
also enables additional user-defined share reference types to be added
in the future.  As a result, `&` pattern matching syntax now works for
both `Ref` and `Intern`, which enables wider use of the latter.

Details
-------

`Ref` and `Intern` are both motivated by the fact that DDlog records are
immutable, and therefore can be copied around by reference, which saves
a lot of memory for large records.

Compared to `Ref`, `Intern` enables faster comparison and hashing
operations at the cost of slower creation plus some locking overhead.

The compiler has some builtin support for both types, but support for
`Ref` is more extensive; most importantly, the `&` syntax allows pattern
matching values inside `Ref`, which is essential in order to store
structured data by reference.

Instead of duplicating the same features for `Intern`, we unify both
types as a new "shared reference" abstraction.  This is possible since
the compiler only really cares that the type implements `Deref` trait in
Rust for the pattern matching functionality.  We introduce a new
annotation applicable to any extern type with exactly one type argument:

 ```
 #[shared_ref]
 extern type XXX<YYY>
 ```

We generalize the implementation of `&`-matching to work for all
`shared_ref` types.

Compare interned values by pointer.

We change the implementnation of `Ord` and `PartialOrd` traits for
`Intern` to compare pointers instead of actual values, which leads to
massive speed-ups, but introduces non-determinism across DDlog runs
(see #663)
